title: 111_s788
content: The "m-SPAM Act of 2009" is cited as the short title. Certain qualifying messages are exempt from the definition of mobile service commercial message. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 is amended to define "mobile service commercial message" as a commercial electronic mail message sent to a wireless device of a subscriber of commercial mobile service without prior consent. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 defines a "mobile service commercial message" as a commercial electronic mail message sent to a wireless device without prior consent, excluding messages related to commercial transactions, warranty information, product recalls, safety information, or ongoing commercial relationships. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 defines a "mobile service commercial message" as a message related to ongoing commercial relationships, including notices of changes in terms or status. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 allows commercial messages related to ongoing relationships, employment benefits, or delivery of goods and services. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 permits commercial messages for ongoing relationships, employment benefits, or delivery of goods and services, including product updates or upgrades. It also specifies definitions for terms like "short message" and "wireless device." The Act does not prohibit certain messages related to short messaging services and mobile commercial messages. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 allows for commercial messages related to ongoing relationships, employment benefits, and product updates. It specifies exemptions for short messaging services and mobile commercial messages, including messages sent at no cost to subscribers unless they opt out. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 allows for commercial messages related to ongoing relationships, employment benefits, and product updates. Amendments include requiring providers of commercial mobile service to comply with regulations. SEC. 3. PROHIBITION ON UNAUTHORIZED MOBILE SERVICE COMMERCIAL MESSAGES CONTAINING UNSOLICITED ADVERTISEMENTS. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to prohibit sending mobile service commercial messages to individuals without their prior authorization. Definitions for terms like 'commercial mobile service' and 'mobile service commercial message' are also provided. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to prohibit sending mobile service commercial messages without prior authorization. The prohibition does not apply to sending short messages between wireless devices or from a commercial mobile service provider to its subscribers at no charge, unless a subscriber opts out. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to prohibit sending mobile service commercial messages without prior authorization, except for messages sent by a provider to its subscribers at no charge unless a subscriber opts out. This Act does not grant states greater authority over mobile service commercial messages than they have over commercial electronic mail messages under the CAN-SPAM Act of 2003. Mobile service commercial messages containing unsolicited advertisements sent to cellular telephones explicitly prohibited under SEC. 4. The Federal Trade Commission will revise the do-not-call registry provisions to prohibit sending unsolicited commercial messages to phone numbers listed on the registry, except for messages sent by a provider of commercial mobile service to its subscribers at no charge. The term "commercial mobile service" is defined in section 332(d) of the Communications Act of 1934 (47 U.S.C. 332(d)), and the term "commercial electronic mail message" is defined in section 14(d) of the CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 (15 U.S.C. 7712(d)).
